title: Steam Header – Blocked Outlet
description: A high-pressure steam header feeds multiple process units. A downstream isolation valve may be inadvertently closed, creating a blocked outlet scenario. The PSV must protect the header from overpressure. Discharge is to atmosphere via a silencer.
constraints: Set pressure at MAWP of 150 psig
Steam is saturated at relieving conditions
No variable backpressure – conventional valve acceptable

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Steam Header
attachments.contentRef: Steam header at 150 psig MAWP. Supply from boiler house. Feeds Unit 100, Unit 200, Unit 300. PSV-101 protects header. Discharge routed to atmosphere via silencer. No backpressure header.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Maximum steam flow from boiler: 25,000 lb/hr. In blocked outlet scenario, full boiler output must be relieved. Steam properties at 150 psig saturated: T = 366°F, MW = 18.02, k = 1.33, Z ≈ 0.95.

title: Gas Service to Flare – Variable Backpressure
description: A process gas compressor discharge vessel requires overpressure protection. The PSV discharges to a common flare header shared with multiple units. During upset conditions, flare header pressure can fluctuate significantly, creating variable backpressure concerns.
constraints: Backpressure exceeds 10% of set pressure – conventional valve NOT suitable

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Compressor Discharge
attachments.contentRef: Compressor K-101 discharge vessel V-101. MAWP 200 psig. PSV-201 on vessel top. Discharge ties into 8" flare header. Header serves Units 100-400. Note: Flare header pressure varies 15-45 psig during upsets.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Relief case: Control valve failure (FV-101 fails open). Max flow: 15,000 lb/hr. Gas: Hydrocarbon mix, MW=32, k=1.25, Z=0.92. Relieving temp: 250°F. Expected built-up BP in discharge piping: ~20 psig.

title: Liquid Thermal Expansion Case
description: A heat exchanger shell containing a liquid hydrocarbon can be blocked in during maintenance or turnaround. Solar radiation or residual heat can cause thermal expansion of the trapped liquid. A thermal relief valve is required to prevent hydraulic overpressure.
constraints: Thermal expansion case – small flow, critical selection

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Heat Exchanger E-101
attachments.contentRef: Shell & Tube Exchanger E-101. Shell side: Light hydrocarbon liquid. MAWP 75 psig. Block valves on inlet/outlet allow isolation. PSV-301 (thermal relief) on shell. Discharge to closed drain header.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Thermal expansion relief: Expected flow ~3 GPM based on heat input calculation. Fluid: Light naphtha, SG=0.68, viscosity ~0.5 cP. Relieving temp assumed 150°F. Closed drain header pressure negligible (<5 psig).
